note_spans.text: Sarah reports that the past two weeks have been challenging[1], with worsening insomnia, now averaging three to four hours of sleep per night.

citations.transcript: Hi. Honestly, it's been a really tough couple of weeks. The insomnia has gotten worse. I'm maybe getting three or four hours a night now, and I feel exhausted all the time.

note_spans.text: She expresses feelings of exhaustion[1] and irritability[2], particularly towards her husband and daughter, Emma.

citations.transcript: My mood has definitely been lower. I've been feeling more irritable with my husband and with Emma, which I hate. I snapped at Emma yesterday for something small and then felt terrible about it. I've also noticed I don't really enjoy things the way I used to. Even reading, which I love, feels like a chore.

Complicated. We've always had a difficult dynamic. She's very critical, especially about how I'm raising Emma. Last week she told me I'm too permissive and that's why Emma has tantrums. I know she's probably wrong, but it still hurts. I ended up crying in the bathroom after she left the room.

note_spans.text: Sarah describes her relationship with her mother as complicated[1], noting that her mother's critical comments about her parenting have triggered feelings of inadequacy and sadness, leading to crying episodes.

citations.transcript: Complicated. We've always had a difficult dynamic. She's very critical, especially about how I'm raising Emma. Last week she told me I'm too permissive and that's why Emma has tantrums. I know she's probably wrong, but it still hurts. I ended up crying in the bathroom after she left the room.

note_spans.text: Sarah appeared fatigued[1] and somewhat anxious during the session.

citations.transcript: Good afternoon, Sarah. It's good to see you again. How have you been doing since our last session two weeks ago?

note_spans.text: Her affect was flat at times, particularly when discussing her mother's criticisms.
She demonstrated insight into her feelings[1] but expressed frustration with her current coping strategies[2], particularly regarding sleep hygiene and boundary-setting with her mother.

citations.transcript: Okay, that sounds good. I know I need to set boundaries with her. It's just so hard. Every time I try, she makes me feel guilty, like I'm being a bad daughter.

It started about a week after our last session. My mom came to stay with us, and things have been really tense. She keeps making comments about my parenting, and I just lie awake at night replaying those conversations.

note_spans.text: Sarah is experiencing increased symptoms of anxiety[1] and depression[2], including insomnia, irritability, and anhedonia.

citations.transcript: My mood has definitely been lower. I've been feeling more irritable with my husband and with Emma, which I hate. I snapped at Emma yesterday for something small and then felt terrible about it. I've also noticed I don't really enjoy things the way I used to. Even reading, which I love, feels like a chore.
Hi. Honestly, it's been a really tough couple of weeks. The insomnia has gotten worse. I'm maybe getting three or four hours a night now, and I feel exhausted all the time.

note_spans.text: The stressor of her mother's visit appears to exacerbate her symptoms[1], indicating a need for improved coping strategies[2] and boundary-setting.

citations.transcript: That sounds like a significant stressor. How is your relationship with your mother typically?
Okay, that sounds good. I know I need to set boundaries with her. It's just so hard. Every time I try, she makes me feel guilty, like I'm being a bad daughter.

note_spans.text: Current medication adherence is good, but she is questioning the efficacy of her sertraline dosage. [1][2][3]

citations.transcript: I'm glad to hear that, and it's clear Emma is a strong protective factor for you. Are you still taking the sertraline as prescribed?

It's good that you're consistent with the medication. Regarding the dose, that's something to discuss with Dr. Martinez. I can include a note about your symptoms in my summary for her. How is the medication sitting with you otherwise? Any side effects?
Yes, 50mg every morning. I haven't missed any doses. Although I've been wondering if maybe we should increase it? A friend of mine is on 100mg and she says it helped her a lot more at that dose.

note_spans.text: Continue with the current medication[1] and discuss potential dosage adjustments with Dr.

citations.transcript: It's good that you're consistent with the medication. Regarding the dose, that's something to discuss with Dr. Martinez. I can include a note about your symptoms in my summary for her. How is the medication sitting with you otherwise? Any side effects?

note_spans.text: Implement a wind-down routine that includes no phone use after 10 PM[1], breathing exercises, and light reading.

citations.transcript: Exactly. Let's also set up a simple wind-down routine - no phone after 10 PM, the breathing exercise, and maybe some light reading instead of screen time. We'll check in on how all of this is going in our next session. Your homework this week is the 9 PM conversation boundary and the phone-free wind-down routine. How are you feeling about that?

note_spans.text: Sarah will practice setting a boundary with her mother by ending conversations by 9 PM. [1][2]

citations.transcript: Setting boundaries with family members who trigger guilt is one of the hardest things to do. It's a skill that takes practice. For this week, I'd like you to try one small boundary - maybe ending conversations by 9 PM. We can role-play how to phrase that before you leave today.

Exactly. Let's also set up a simple wind-down routine - no phone after 10 PM, the breathing exercise, and maybe some light reading instead of screen time. We'll check in on how all of this is going in our next session. Your homework this week is the 9 PM conversation boundary and the phone-free wind-down routine. How are you feeling about that?

note_spans.text: Follow up on these strategies in the next session to assess progress and make necessary adjustments.
